query: What are the most effective ways to manage uncropped field margins on European farmland to support bumblebees?
relevant_summary:
Several methods have been studied for managing uncropped field margins to support bumblebees. Sowing field margins with an agricultural nectar and pollen seed mix has been shown to attract significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped field margins (18). In some trials, a mix of agricultural forage plants attracted more bumblebees than a perennial wildflower mix in the first year, but these margins may need to be re-sown every few years to maintain their value for bumblebees (18).

Sowing uncropped field margins with a native wild flower seed mix has also been found to support a higher abundance and species richness of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated uncropped margins (19). For long-tongued bumblebee species, perennial leguminous herbs in the seed mixtures are particularly important forage sources (19).

Leaving arable field margins to regenerate naturally can result in more bumblebees compared to cropped margins, but the value of these margins can be inconsistent from year to year and may depend on the presence of thistle species, which are often considered pernicious weeds (20).

There is no evidence on the effects of these field margin management strategies on solitary bees (18, 19, 20).
